column4: what's the command to delete somehting in /usr/bin? got something else to delete, i will remember this time!
er, what are you deleting?
you should remove the package, instead of deleting things manually
which package?
which file exactly?
and, `dpkg -l | grep qemu` doesn't return anything?
if it were the windows version, it wouldn't be there.
`dpkg -l | grep qemu` doesn't return anything?
that's in your home dir.  ~/.wine/drive_c/
very odd.  That really shouldn't still be there, unless you were playing around with other installation methods.  Anyway, sudo rm /usr/bin/qemu will do it.
what are you using to 'see' that it's there?
Ah.  Hit ... uh, f5?  Look for reload in the menus
nautilus doesn't refresh stuff right away.  You were seeing a ghost ;)
ubuntu doesn't use the root account, we use sudo.
just console - sudo nano /file/path/stuff
you don't want to run things at root.
use `sudo -i` to open a root prompt
but, you shouldn't be manually changing permissions on external harddrives.  You should be mounting them more appropriately
sudo commands  don't exist.  Running as root is the same thing as prepending sudo.  Sudo just runs the commands as root.
to run as root, you STILL need to know the commands.  It's absolutely NO different.
sudo, or gksudo if it's a graphical program
oh, look at that.  Jowi beat me to it... using identical text.
